info.game_comments:
Dave Leach game 7.
Dan McShane game 1.

jeopardy_round: SNAKES... WHY'D IT HAVE TO BE SNAKES?

(1, 1).clue: New Mexico's largest city, it was named for a viceroy of New Spain

(2, 1).clue: Holy jumpin' cats!  Here's an African sand cat squaring off with a sand viper in this 3-million-square-mile sandpile

(4, 1).clue: The simplest version of IRS Form 1040 adds these 2 letters

(5, 1).clue: A small piano about 5 feet long

(6, 1).clue: In Genesis he wakes up to find himself minus one rib but plus one female

(1, 2).clue: The animal seen here was rescued in New Mexico's capitan mountains & became the living symbol of this mascot

(2, 2).clue: Sibon annulata, named for preying on these very slow movers, lives in central America, not France

(4, 2).clue: To get the 411, submit an eFOIA (Freedom of Information Act) form to this Justice Dept. main investigative body

(5, 2).clue: Louise Brown's arrival in 1978 made her the first successful one of these in vitro creations

(6, 2).clue: In architecture a ribbed ceiling with arches is called one of these, like a room in a bank

(1, 3).clue: In 1942 this comparatively isolated New Mexico place was chosen for an atomic research lab

(2, 3).clue: The modern-day Rikki-Tikki-Tavis here are watching one of these snakes emerging from a hole

(4, 3).clue: In form VA4962, Verification of Eligibility for Burial in a National Cemetery, VA is this Cabinet department

(5, 3).clue: In 2007 the first of these, born 1 second after midnight January 1, 1946, filed for social security

(6, 3).clue: This cotton fabric with vertical raised ribs comes in wide wale & pinwale varieties

(1, 4).clue: Lilian Whiting used this phrase as the title of a 1906 book; it became New Mexico's official state nickname in 1999

(2, 4).clue: You can tell by its stripes that the deadly Australian snake here is named for this big cat

(4, 4).clue: 302-AM is an application for a broadcast station license with this agency

(5, 4).clue: At diapers.com power outlet covers are listed among the "essentials" for this activity

(6, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows an anatomical animation on the monitor.)  The lowest two pairs of ribs in humans are known by this suspended adjective, as they don't attach in the front

(1, 5).clue: Most of what is now New Mexico was ceded to the U.S. in 1848 through this treaty that ended the Mexican War

(2, 5).clue: The prominent horn on the nose shows why Bitis nasicornis is also known as this viper, after another African animal

(4, 5).clue: These 3 letters refer to a Cabinet department & precede 30106 in a sample move in/move out inspection form

(5, 5).clue: This youthful fellow had a bad run-in with the authorities in 1934

(6, 5).clue: The ribs of a boat's frame, they're "shiver"ed in a salty expression

(1, 1).clue: As the story goes, this poem was written on December 24, 1822 on the way home with a turkey for dinner
(1, 1).correct response: "\'Twas the Night Before Christmas" ("A Visit From St. Nicholas")

(2, 1).clue: Send a one-hopper home to get the guy who tagged up; shoot it around the horn

(3, 1).clue: This Italian term for the deepest male voice range can precede profundo or continuo

(4, 1).clue: Though spelled differently, it's the real first name of Diddy & Jay-Z

(5, 1).clue: Thousands have died in this country's 2011 uprising against the Assad regime

(1, 2).clue: H. Rider Haggard is said to have penned "King Solomon's" these in a little over a month to back up a boast he'd made

(2, 2).clue: In a Namco game, eat fruit, dodge ghosts, get the hungry gal around the maze

(3, 2).clue: It's the time signature of the Chopin piece heard here; listen to the left hand

(4, 2).clue: Like late actor Nielsen, Gerald Ford had this given first name

(5, 2).clue: In 2011 the New York Times it was a-changin' as Jill Abramson became its first female executive this

(1, 3).clue: He wrote "The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby" in one night for Esquire magazine

(2, 3).clue: Clear the zone; stay out of the crease when trying to score on the power play

(3, 3).clue: In 1990, on this composer's 150th birthday, Itzhak Perlman was fiddling away in Russia in his honor

(4, 3).clue: Telly Savalas may not have had Mr. Onassis' money, but he did share this intellectual first name

(5, 3).clue: A hunger strike by Anna Hazare forced India's govt. to agree to this type of "man" investigating corruption

(6, 3).clue: Surrounding words that give meaning:next cot

(1, 4).clue: For a magazine story, this author of westerns once did his day's writing on a traffic island on Sunset Blvd.

(2, 4).clue: Roll dice & try to get your 15 counters off the board before the other guy; watch out for doubling

(3, 4).clue: The name of this instrument consisting of steel bars on a frame is from the German for "play of bells"

(4, 4).clue: In Spanish please, it's the real first name of Chuck Norris & Charlie Sheen

(5, 4).clue: This country's leader tried to squash rumors of his ill health with tweets from his account @chavezcandanga

(6, 4).clue: Misplaced or not, it adds meaning:if do re mi

(1, 5).clue: Unable to sleep, Longfellow knocked out "The Wreck Of" this ship between midnight & 3 A.M.

(2, 5).clue: As Master Chief, shoot at the Covenant, massacre the flood; rinse, repeat

(3, 5).clue: In 1888 John Philip Sousa wrote this march that later became the official march of the Marine Corps

(4, 5).clue: Paul McCartney's real first name; he shares it with 2 apostles

(5, 5).clue: In 2011 the Kimberly Process regulating these "sanguine" items allowed Zimbabwe to sell certain gems

(0, 0).clue: The Hebrew word for this Biblical unit of measurement is Ammah, aptly meaning "elbow" or "forearm"
